Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Smart Power Distribution System Curriculum - Multi-Institution Demonstration and Deployment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The steady modernization of electric power distribution systems has included the installation of smart grid enabling technology such as intelligent electronic devices (IED) equipped with their own internal sensors, mini-RTU's (remote terminal units) which measure network flows, and Automatic Meter Reading (AMR) for sensing network loads. While these devices have increased the level of digital control available within power distribution networks, they use varied communication protocols. In addition, significant efforts to increase the amount of renewable and distributed energy sources/storage have been made by state and local governments, yet in some areas, network limits have been reached.

The proposed power distribution system curriculum is designed to educate students in the operation and planning of smart electric power distribution systems. The curriculum centers around a reconfigurable distribution automation and control (RDAC) laboratory coupled with software programs to visualize collected data and to control the distribution system. Project tasks include teaching and lab materials development, implementation and evaluation as well as faculty development.

The project will create mature versions of previous work by making necessary adaptations for implementation and testing at multiple academic institutions. The subsequent evaluation procedure for these enhanced materials will create a process such that new learning materials developed under this project are expected to also yield successful course and laboratory modules that could be widely distributed. The project will contribute to the effort to modernize the curriculum on power distribution system in the nation's universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Key outcomes of the project were development of software PV modules and microgrid module to be integrated in classroom and using MATLAB and executable file to reach more users. Design and development of photovoltaic (PV) visualization module for different scenarios helps to understand key concepts associated with PV integration. Developed PV modules has following features:

a)     PV visualization module in multiple platforms that can demonstrate PV characteristics for different time during the day, different seasona, as well as different geographical location

b)     Ability to analyze the output power of the PV panel for maximum power point as well as for constant load impedance

c)     Ability to analyze scheduling of specific load, such as dc machines, that can only work when power, current and voltage exceed the threshold.

 

This project allowed supporting three graduate students partially. One female MS student, J. Wei graduated during this period and secured a job at Monitoring Analytics LLC, PA in distribution system economics analysis very relevant to this project. J. Wei worked on developing software modules in this project. Another MS student S. Chanda graduated and secured a job at Idaho National Lab and will be working on research related to distribution system and microgrid resiliency. S. Chanda worked on developing course modules as part of this project and also helped developing a tutorial at major IEEE conference. This project partially supported a Ph.D. student Ramon Zamora, who is now working as a assistant professor at Auckland University of Technology (AUT) and will potentially test the modules in Advancements in Solar Energy course at AUT. This project helped training three graduate students and contributed towards workforce development for power distribution system.

Results has been disseminated using PI’s website and sending information to POWERGLOBE mailing list. We will also publish in conferences and Journal, once we have the student’s feedback from courses using this module. We are still working on improving the course material and dissemination will be next step in Spring 2017 and Summer 2017.
